head.title: But Do They Have a Honey Pot for ''Winnie-the-Pooh''?

identified-content.classifier: Top/Classifieds/Job Market/Job Categories/Hospitality, Restaurant and Travel

hedline.hl1: But Do They Have a Honey Pot for ''Winnie-the-Pooh''?

abstract.p: Read, Brooklyn, combines used-book store and cafe; photo (S)

block.p: Food for mind and body is on the menu in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, at the Read, 158 Bedford Avenue (North Eighth Street), a slightly threadbare but friendly used-book store and cafe. There, you might find an old copy of ''Slaughterhouse-Five'' by Kurt Vonnegut, to read while nibbling the chicken-walnut salad sandwich ($6) named after him. (Don't worry: the Melville sandwich features tuna, not whale.)

The cafe has tables for about 20, with some more in a garden in the back. It serves every espresso-based drink imaginable. A highlight among the desserts is fresh peach cobbler, $3.50. New periodicals are as diverse as The Economist, Self and Punk Planet.

Food for mind and body is on the menu in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, at the Read, 158 Bedford Avenue (North Eighth Street), a slightly threadbare but friendly used-book store and cafe. There, you might find an old copy of ''Slaughterhouse-Five'' by Kurt Vonnegut, to read while nibbling the chicken-walnut salad sandwich ($6) named after him. (Don't worry: the Melville sandwich features tuna, not whale.)

The cafe has tables for about 20, with some more in a garden in the back. It serves every espresso-based drink imaginable. A highlight among the desserts is fresh peach cobbler, $3.50. New periodicals are as diverse as The Economist, Self and Punk Planet.
The Read opens at 7 a.m. weekdays and 9 a.m. Saturday and Sunday, and stays open until 11 p.m. Monday through Wednesday, 2 a.m. Thursday through Saturday and 9 p.m. Sunday.
